The gas engine is an internal gas combustion engine, such as coal gas, generator gas, biogas, landfill gas (methane) or natural gas. In general, the gas engine refers to an industrial engine with heavy operational loads capable of operating continuously during full pregnancy for periods of approximately 8760 hours per year, unlike the petrol engine for cars, lightweight, which rotates at a high speed and usually does not exceed 4,000 hours in its operational life. Gas engine capacity ranges from 13 horsepower (10 kW) to 5364 horsepower (400 kW). The grounds for divorce vary considerably from country to country. Marriage may be regarded as a social contract or legal status or a combination thereof. Wha marriage is regarded as a contract, the refusal or inability of one of the spouses to perform the obligations stipulated in the contract may constitute a reason for the other party to request a divorce. In contrast, in some countries (e.g. Sweden, Finland, Australia and New Zealand) there is a so-called (absolute divorce), which means that it does not matter why individuals/spouses wish to secede, since couples can secede of their own free will without the need for one party to prove the other party ' s fault or default. Many judicial authorities in several countries have offered both the option of divorce without error as well as divorce for error, for example in many American states or in the Czech Republic. Although divorce laws differ among judicial authorities in States, there are two basic methods of divorce: divorce without error or divorce with error. However, in some judicial authorities, which do not require a party to make a false claim by its partner, the court may still take into account the behaviour of spouses in the division of property and debts and in the evaluation of matters relating to custody, joint care and support for children. In some States, the judicial authorities may force one of the spouses to pay for the counsel of the other party. The laws also differ with regard to the period of time after which divorce becomes effective, as well as the requirements for residence or residence, yet cases of division of property are usually determined by the law of the judicial authorities in which the property is located. In Europe divorce laws vary from country to country, reflecting different legal and cultural traditions.

Many primary schools have also begun teaching English. The use of information technology in education development has recently increased and most schools have beconnected to the Internet. Students also learn Japanese traditional arts such as the Chodo - Line of Hand - and the Haiku. Chodo is the art of inking brushes and using them to write the kanji - the letters used in some East Asian countries and each of our own crafts - and the cana - the voice letters quoted from the kanji - in a technical way. Haiku is a special style of hair that has bespreading in Japan for 400 years. It consists of a short house divided into 17 sections divided into units of five, sevand five. The haiku uses simple expressions to convey deep feelings to the reader. Students in Japanese primary schools are divided into small teams to engage in many activities. For example, students clean classrooms, halls and schoolyards every day. In many primary schools, pupils take lunch classes at the school or local centre for the preparation of lunch for schools in the neighbourhood.

Images takat a distance of about 4.2 billion kilometres confirmed the ability of the spacecraft to track remote targets, which is important for exploring towards Pluto and other Koeper belt objects. In early 2007, the vehicle benefited from the buyer ' s gravitational assistance. The New Horizons spacecraft approached Pluto on July 14, 2015, after a 3462-day flight through the solar system. Pluto's scientific observations began five months before the nearest approach and lasted at least a month after the meeting. The observations were made using the remote sensing package, which included photographic and radio science investigative tools, as well as spectral and other experiments.

In Syria, pre-university education is divided into two stages: basic education from 6 to 15 years of age, consisting of two cycles; secondary education from 15 to 18 years of age, comprising three branches, namely scientific, literary and legal; and sevvocational branches, namely, industrial, agricultural, commercial, tourist, information and artistic. The student finishes with the general secondary school certificate, which qualifys him at his rate and, based on a trade-off issued by the Ministry of Higher Education, his final competence in universities. The majority of Syrians are going to study at State universities, the oldest being Damascus University. In 1972, the State enacted a law on literacy, but it has not fully implemented it. The illiteracy rate fell from 19% in 2000 to 14.2% in 2008, making Syria the ninth Arab and 119th international literacy rate. A large number of cultural festivals and book fairs are held annually in the country, notably the Damascus Book Fair. The Government runs a number of libraries and reading rooms. The most prominent public libraries are probably the Assad National Library. The cities also contain provincial and district centres, cultural houses and theatres run by the Ministry of Culture, and small public libraries, through which festivals and other cultural days are organized. Investing in the health sector, the State intervenes alongside the private sector. The Government runs 85 hospitals in the Republic, the majority of which are of a large specialized nature, along with some 800 health clinics in rural areas. In addition to these hospitals under the Ministry of Health, there are 12 university hospitals under the Ministry of Higher Education and 18 military hospitals under the Ministry of Defence. In 2008, there were some 400 private hospitals covering about 25% of the entire health sector, as well as a large number of private health clinics run by Syrian doctors, all under the supervision of the Ministry of Health. The Government deducts part of the salaries of employees working in the public sector, as health insurance in its health facilities. Under the established laws, private companies are also required to register their employees in health and social insurance, whether in public or private institutions.

Estonia (in Estonian: Eesti), officially the Republic of Estonia (in Estonian: Eesti Vabariik); is a State in the Baltic Sea region of northern Europe. It is bounded in the north by the Gulf of Finland, in the west by the Baltic Sea, in the south by Latvia (343 km) and in the east by Lake Pipos and the Russian Federation (338.6 km). The territory of Estonia covers an area of 45227 square kilometres (17462) and its seasonal climate is moderate. Estonian is the only official language in the country. Estonia is a parliamentary democratic republic, divided into 15 provinces. The capital and its largest city, the capital, Talin. Its population is 1,319,133 million. It is also one of the least developed members in terms of population in the European Union, the euro area and NATO. It has the highest per capita GDP among the republics of the former Soviet Union. The Republic of Estonia was described as a high-income economy by the World Bank and as a developed economy by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), and later became a member of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). The United Nations ranks Estonia as a developed country, and the human development index is very high. They also enjoy a high standard of freedom of the press, economic and political freedom, and education. Officially called the Republic of Estonia (Eesti Vabariik-Esti Fabarek) Estonia is named after the Roman writer Tacíz, who in his book is a German who described a group of people called Aesti. In the ancient Scandinavian sanctuaries, it refers to a country called Estland, which is Estonia's name in modern Germanic languages. The land border with Estonia and Latvia extends 267 kilometres from the Russian border and extends 290 kilometres. From 1920 to 1945, Estonia ' s border with Russia, established by the Treaty of Peace of Tartu 1920, sought beyond the Narva River in the north-east of the country and beyond from the town of Pechory (Petsiri) in the south-east of the country.

The measurement of long-term interference (Viry-long-baseline interferometry) is a type of astronomical interferometry used in radio astronomy. In LBI, a signal is collected from an astronomical radio source, such as cosarse stars, using multiple radio telescopes on Earth or in space. The distance betweradio telescopes is thcalculated using the time difference betwethe radio signal and the different telescopes. This allows for the simultaneous detection of an offence by several radio telescopes, which simulates the use of one large telescope of a size equal to the maximum distance betwetelescopes. The data received in the matrix antennas include signal arrival times using a local atomic clock, such as hydrogmess. Later, data are collected with other antenna data that recorded the same radio signal, to produce the final image. The accuracy that can be achieved using an overlap measure is proportional to the frequency of monitoring. The LBI technique allows the distance betwetelescopes to be much greater than that possible using conventional interferometry, which requires the delivery of antennas by a pivot cable, wave guide, optical fibres or any other type of electrical transmission line. More distance can be achieved in LBI by means of the closure technology developed by Roger Jenson in the 1950s, which allows LBI to produce much more accurate images. LBI techniques are used to capture remote cosmic radio sources, and to track spacecraft, as well as other applications in astronomical measurement. However, givthat an LBI technique measures the time differences betweradio waves ' access to separate antennas, it can also be used in a counter-productive way to conduct studies on Earth circulation, tectonic plate movements very accurately (within millimetres), and other studies on geodesy.

More recently, especially in environmental policy, the term " climate change " is used to refer only to recent climate changes, and the most important change they point to is the change in the temperature of the Earth ' s surface, which is called global warming. The term is sometimes used to refer to the human causes of climate change, as is the case in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). This Convention uses the term " climate variability " to refer to non-human causes. In fact, the Earth has undergone many climate changes in the past, including four ice ages in the past, and weather conditions are colder than usual during these times, separated by ice ages. The accumulation of snow and ice leads to an increase in surface whites, which increases the reflection of sunlight into space, maintaining low atmospheric temperature. Volcanic activity, among others, increases the proportion of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, thus helping to increase the temperature and the incidence of ice interstellar periods (a hot period betwethe two glaciers). Possible causes of glaciers include changes in the location of continents, changes in Earth's orbit, changes in solar energy production and volcanoes. Climate models are used to simulate the Earth ' s atmosphere, oceans, surfaces and ice in quantitative ways. They are thused in many different studies, such as the study of the dynamics of the weather and climate system to the study of the outlook for future climate. All climate models are balanced, or they may be almost balanced. This balance is betwethe electromagnetic energy coming into the Earth, such as short waves (including visible) and the electromagnetic energy released, such as long waves (including infrared). Any imbalance in this balance results in a change in the temperature of the planet. In recent years, the consequences of increasing greenhouse gases in these models, particularly carbon dioxide, have bemuch mentioned.

The first models for studying cosmology were superstitions, as most of the ancient attempts were based mainly on a form of fragmentation (i.e., the ratio of human attributes to non-human beings). The space programme of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, known as the Soviet Space Programme, is the national space programme of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which was activated from the 1930s until the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991. The Soviet space programme was based mainly on the discovery of space by Russian astronauts and on the development of launch vehicles, which were divided among many competing design offices. In 60 years of its history, the Russian space programme has beresponsible for a number of ground-breaking events and achievements in human space flights, including the intercontinental ballistic rocket R-7, the first satellite (Sputnik 1), the dispatch of the first animal into Earth orbit (Lika's dog on Sputnik 2), the dispatch of the first human into space and into Earth orbit (Uri Jajarin on Vostok 1), the dispatch of the first woman into space and in Earth orbit (Salterna Trechkova on Vostok 6), the first space-walking operation (Alexi Leonov on Voskhod 2), the first moon-surface impact (Luna 2), the first picture of the distant side of the Moon (Luna 3) and the peaceful landing on the Moon by an uninhabited vehicle (Luna 9), the dispatch of the first space rover (Lunjod 1), the automatic extraction and sending to Earth of the first sample of the Moon soil (Luna 16), and the construction of the first space station (Salot 1). In addition, some of the recorded achievements included sending first probes to the centre betwethe two planets: Vinera 1 and Mars 1 to fly near Venera and Mars respectively, Vinera 3 and Mars 2, which collided with the surface of Venera and Mars respectively, Vinnera 7 and Mars 3, which landed peacefully on those planets.

In 1972, India enacted the Wildlife Protection Act and the Tiger Project to protect important wildlife. The Forest Conservation Act was enacted in 1980 and amendments were added in 1988. India hosts over 500 wildlife and 13 biosphere reserves, four of which are part of the Global Biosphere Reserves Network; 25 wetlands have beregistered under the Ramsar Convention. India is the world ' s largest democratic nation in terms of population. It is a parliamentary republic with a multi-party system, with eight recognized national parties, including the Indian National Congress Party, the Bharatiya Janata Party (PJB) and more than 40 regional parties. The Indian National Congress Party is from the centre left in Indian political culture, and Bharatiya Janata is a right-wing party. During most of the period betwe1950 - whIndia became a republic for the first time - and the late 1980s, the Congress Party had a majority in Parliament. Since then, however, it has increasingly beinvolved in the political arena with the BJP, as well as with the powerful regional parties, which have oftimposed the formation of multi-party coalition governments signed into the political mainstream. In the first three general elections of the Republic of India, in 1951, 1957 and 1962, the Congress Party under the leadership of Jawaharlal Nehru achieved easy victories. WhNehru died in 1964, Lal Bahadur Shastri briefly became Prime Minister; after his unexpected death in 1966, he was succeeded by the daughter of Nehru Andera Gandhi, who led Congress to electoral victories in 1967 and 1971. After the general dissatisfaction with the state of emergency declared in 1975, the Congress Party lost power in 1977; the thnew Janata Party, which opposed the state of emergency, continued its government for just over two years.

The study concluded that pollution is one of the greatest existential challenges in the Anthropocene era, as pollution threatens the stability of land-support systems and the survival of human societies. Pollution is widespread in the environment. There are a number of implications: a study published in 2022 in the journal Environmental Science and Technology found that levels of human chemical pollution have exceeded the planet ' s capacity to sustain them and today pollution is threatening entire ecosystems around the world. A 2021 study found that exposure to pollution leads to an increase in violent crime. New research from the School of Public Health and Colorado State University has also shown that inhalation of contaminated air up to one day is likely to make people more aggressive and violent. The study also stated that pollution could make simple, everyday conflicts such as arguing with a neighbour rapidly rage and lead to more dangerous physical altercations. A scientific paper found a relationship betwepollution and low student educational attainment, with pollution causing exhaustion, absence from school and distractions. Several studies have shown that pollution has a negative impact on the productivity of both domestic and external workers. Another study to show the causal relationship betweair pollution and labour productivity showed that an increase of 10 units in the air pollution index resulted in a 4% reduction in labour productivity. To protect the environment from the harmful effects of pollution, many States around the world have introduced laws to regulate various types of pollution as well as to mitigate the harmful effects of pollution. The term (pollution control) is used in the management of environmental resources and means the control of emissions and liquid wastes in air, water or soil. Without pollution control, waste from excessive consumption, heating, agriculture, mining, manufacturing, transport and other human activities, whether accumulated or degraded, will lead to environmental degradation.

The term decolonization was used to refer to cultural decolonization from colonial ideas that made the colony feel inferior. Decolonization issues continue to exist and to be raised contemporaryally. Such issues are increasingly being discussed in Latin America and South Africa under the term "dicolonism" (cultural separation from colonialism). There was momentum for decolonization at the end of the First World War, particularly through the League of Nations, especially for European territories under the control of the Ottoman and Austrian Hungarian empires. Under Article 22 of the Charter of the League of Nations, several States were placed under mandate. The stated intention was to prepare these countries for self-government, but the mandate is oftinterpreted as merely a redistribution of control over the former non-European colonies of defeated powers, especially the German Empire and the Ottoman Empire. This reassignment work continued through the United Nations, with a similar regime of territories under international trusteeship established to modify control over both former colonies and mandated territories. The 1960 United Nations Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples was a milestone in decolonization. Researchers have proposed different interpretations of decolonization trends. Two prominent interpretations emphasize the state of the world economy (e.g. whether there is dominance, economic growth or stagnation) and the theory of the world political system (which emphasizes the spread of the model of a nation-state from Western Europe to dependency and contagion, where decolonization takes place in one case leading to subsequent decolonization in other cases). Other interpretations confirmed how the decline in the profitability of colonialism and the costs associated with the empire had led to decolonization. Some explanations confirm how the colonial powers have fought militarily against the rebels in the colonies because of the shift from the conditions of the nineteenth century of strong political will, a tolerant international environment, access to local collaborators, and flexibility in choosing their battles against the circumstances of the twentieth century such as the heroic masses, the hostile superpowers, the lack of collaborators, and restrictive choices.

India ' s climate is strongly influenced by Himalayas and Tharr deserts, both leading to seasonal winds. The Himalayas prevent the attainment of cold, footwinds coming from Central Asia, keeping much of the Indian subcontinent warmer than most of the areas with which it is located on the same latitude. The Tharr desert plays a major role in attracting monsoon-bearing humidity south-west betweJune and October to provide India with most of its rains. Four major climate groups are prevalent in India: humid tropical, dry tropical, subtropical wet and mountainous. India is a very diverse country, a term used for 17 countries with high biodiversity and many indigenous or endemic species. India is home to 8.6% of all types of mammals, 13.7% of species of birds, 7.9% of reptile species, 6% of species of amphibians, 12.2% of species of fish, and 6.0% of all types of flowering plants. One third of Indian plants are endemic. India also contains four of the 34 biodiversity focal points in the world, or areas showing significant habitat loss with a high endemic presence.b] India ' s forest cover is 701,673 km2 (270,917 m2), representing 21.35% of the country ' s total land area. It can be divided into broad categories of parachute density, or the proportion of forest area covered by the tree umbrella, a very dense forest of more than 70%, occupying 2.61% of the country ' s land area. It prevails in the humid tropical forest of the Andman Islands and the West and North-East Indian Gates. Modest-density forest, with density ranging from 40% to 70%, occupies 9.59 percent of the land area of India. Moderate pineal forests prevail in the Himalayan mountains, the harsh, wet-shura forests in eastern India, and the dry-sage wood forest in central and southern India.

Note that each extra bond removes two hydrogatoms, and saturated hydrocarbons can get four hydrogatoms because of the unique presence of the four carbon electrons.

Ion detectors were first sold in the United States in 1951; they were used in important industrial and commercial enterprises in the years that followed because of the large volume and high cost. In 1955, a high-temperature home detector was developed and the U.S. Atomic Energy Authority granted the first permit for the distribution of smoke detectors using radioactive materials in 1963. The first low-cost smoke detector developed by Duane Dewey Persal in 1965, is a battery-drivmachine that replaces and is easy to install. "SmokeGard 700" is a beehive, made of fire-resistant metal. An intergalactic star or a rogue star is a star that does not exist within a galaxy. Such rare stars move quickly and do not follow a star system together. These stars were the source of much debate in the scientific community during the late 1990s and are believed to be the result of the collision of galaxies, or the break-up of binary stars as they approach a black hole (most galaxies have a black hole in their center, attributed to a galaxy around them; the search showed that there is a black hole in our galaxy with a mass of 2 million solar blocks). The prevailing belief was that stars existed only in galaxies, but this idea was refuted in 1997 with the discovery of a rogue star. It was the first discovery in the conglomerate of virgin galaxies, now believed to be a trillion stars of this kind. The rogue stars are dealing with the problem of lost barion. Pariones, a category of subatomic particles such as protons and neutrons that form the nucleus of atoms in normal matter. Many theories of the formation and evolution of the universe address this dilemma and suggest that the paraiones should be more than those found by scientists. Although the way these stars emerge is still a mystery, the more common theory is that the collision of two or more galaxies can throw some stars out into empty space betwegalaxies. It is believed that these rogue stars may come from very small galaxies, because their gravity is weak and easy to escape. Another theory is that stars can come out of a galaxy because of a supermassive black hole in this case, a rogue star is associated with another star (a binary star), one of which is pulled into a black hole in the center of the galaxy, the other star moves close to the hole and thslips away from its appeal.

Pumps are classified according to the principle of work and the way in which liquid pressure is increased to two main types: dynamic Pumps are divided into two main types: dynamic Pumps continuously raise liquid pressure by converting the liquid's kinetic energy into pressure using the Shaft axis and the Impeller thruster or fan. This type of pump operates with the principle of Bernoli, which states that liquid pressure increases if it is less rapid, so these pumps first increase the fluid speed by using the fan or defense to obtain motor energy, and thconvert this kinetic energy into pressure by increasing the pump exit space or so-called volute. The increased output space reduces the speed of the liquid, which in turn increases the pressure as provided for in the Bernoulli principle. According to the design code No. 610 issued by the American Petroleum Institute (API 610), the design code adopted by most engineers and designers in the world, centrifuge pumps (Centrifugal Pumps) are divided into three subspecies: (Positive Displacement Pumps) which lifts the pressure of the liquid by restricting it to a fixed-sized place, forcing the liquid to escape from the pump exit because of the liquid (non-pressure) characteristic. One of the advantages of this type of pump is that high pressure can be obtained for liquids compared to the previous type. However, one of its most important shortcomings is its high operational cost due to the large number of mobile parts. The pressure generated by these pumps depends on the amount of displacement (Housing Size) and the speed of circulation of the pump. Safety valve on the Discharge pipe line must always be used in this type of pump to avoid a fracture of pipes due to high pressure and vibration caused by movement.

The judicial system of the Russian Empire was established in the mid-19th century, whCaesar Alexander II undertook a comprehensive reform of the judiciary in his country. This system was based in part on both the English judicial system and the French judicial system, and was based on some basic principles: the separation of the judiciary from the administrative branch; the independence of judges and courts; the publicity of trials and the oral nature of proceedings; and the equality of all members of different social classes before the law. Furthermore, democracy had beintroduced through the adoption of the jury system and the election of judges. The establishment of a judicial system based on these principles has bea radical shift in view of the Russian State, since it is no longer considered to be tyrannical, having limited the adjudication of disputes to courts that are not subject to executive authority. This has made the judicial system immune to bureaucracy in its bad sense, but during the last years of Alexander II and during Alexander III, several attempts have bemade to gradually re-establish and restore the competencies granted to the judiciary to Caesar. instantaneous speed can be defined as speed at a givmoment or constant speed within a very short period of time. By looking at the velocity meter, a person can measure the instantaneous velocity of the car at any moment. If the vehicle runs at 50 km per hour, it will travel within an hour of 50 km if it travels at the same speed during that period. If the vehicle continues to walk for half an hour, it will travel a distance of 25 km. If it lasts for one minute, it'll travel 833 meters. In the mathematical sense, velocity is the amount of the velocity vector that results from the derivative of the R site for time. If the length of the cut-off path in t time is the velocity is equal to the derivative: in the graph language, the instantaneous velocity is the slope of the tangent line at any point on the curve of the distance with the time while the hypotenuse on the curve itself reflects the medium velocity during the time covered by the string line. Medium speed can be defined as the total distance travelled during a time. For example, if the distance is 80 km per hour, the average speed is 80 km per hour. If an estimated 320 km is travelled at 4 hours, the average speed is also 80 km per hour. By dividing the distance by a kilometer over time by hours, we get the speed per unit of quantity per hour. Medium speed does not describe the change in speed that can occur during the total time of the distance travelled as it results from dividing the total distance travelled over its total time. The distance travelled can be measured if both the average velocity and the time are known: if the average velocity is 80 km per hour and the time is equal to four hours, the distance is 320 km.

Djibouti or (officially: Republic of Djibouti) (in Somali: Jabuuti Jamhuriyadda) is an Arab State in the Horn of Africa and is a member of the League of Arab States and the African Union. It is located on the western shore of the Bab al-Mandeb Strait, bordered by Eritrea from the north, Ethiopia from the west, south and Somalia from the south-east, and eastward on the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden. On the opposite side across the Red Sea in the Arabian Peninsula of Yemen, its coastline is about 20 kilometres from Djibouti. Djibouti is estimated to have an area of only 23,200 square kilometres, with an estimated population of about 1,000, with Djibouti City as its capital. Nearly one fifth of the country ' s population lives below the global poverty line by approximately $1.25 a day. It was called the French country of Somalia. The ancient Egyptians are the first to establish relations with this part of the world, since the first Egyptian naval mission to this region was in the third thousand B.C.E. During Pharaoh's reign Egypt's first Bebe. However, the Horn of Africa ' s relations with the south-west of the Arabian peninsula are more stable than with the Egyptians. With the beginning of the space age, humans, after examining soil samples from planets through space probes, discovered several common properties betweplanet Earth and other planets, such as volcanic nature, the presence of hurricanes and tectonics (the distortion process that changes the shape of the Earth ' s crust, mutating continents and mountains) and evhydrology. Since 1992, after the discovery of hundreds of planets outside the solar system (i.e., orbiting other stars), scientists have realized that all planets in the Milky Way galaxy share many properties with the planet. The planets are generally divided into two main types: the major planets, which are giant planets of low-density gases, and smaller planets of a rocky nature, such as the planet Earth. According to the International Astronomical Union definitions, the solar system consists of eight planets. The order of these planets after the sun begins with the four rock planets Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars, and ththe giant gas planets Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune. The solar system also contains five dwarf planets: Ceres, Pluto (formerly classified as nine planets in the solar system), Mikmek, Homia and Iris. Each of those planets orbits one or more moons except Mercury, Venus, Ceres and Mikmeek. By March 2009, 344 planets had bediscovered outside the solar system and their size and nature varied from giant gas planets to small planets of rocky nature. The planets, whwe see them at night, show that they bring light, but reflect the light of the sun, and show that they are bright. Several thousand planets have bediscovered around other stars (the planets outside the solar system or the outer planets) in the Milky Way. On 20 December 2011, the Kepler Space Telescope team reported the discovery of the first planets out of the solar system the size of the Earth, Kepler 20 E and Kepler 20 F, orbiting around a Sunlike Star, Kepler 20.

In 1944, the Allies liberated France in the so-called Normandy landing, while the Soviet Union recovered all the areas it had lost and invaded Germany and its allies. In 1944 and 1945, Japan regressed in south central China and in the Burma campaign, while the Allies paralyzed the Japanese Imperial Navy and took control of the main islands in the Pacific. The war in Europe ended with the invasion of Germany by the Allies, the control of Berlin by the Soviet Union and the unconditional surrender of Germany on May 8, 1945. The Potsdam conference was thheld near Berlin, during which the Potsdam Declaration was issued on 26 June 1945, and on 6 August and 9 August 1945 the United States dropped two nuclear bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki (in turn), followed by the surrender of Japan on 15 August 1945. The Second World War changed the world ' s political and military map and social structure, and led to the creation of the United Nations to strengthinternational cooperation and prevent future conflicts. The winning Powers of the war, the United States, the Soviet Union, China, the United Kingdom and France, became permanent members of the United Nations Security Council. The United States and the Soviet Union have emerged as superpowers on the international scene and the influence of European Powers has diminished. This paved the way for the cold war, which has continued in the next 46 years. Countries where industry has beaffected have gone to reform their economic situation, but at the political level, specifically in Europe, an integration phase has begun in an effort to avoid war-caused hostilities, and Europeans have a common identity. In general, the beginning date of the war is September 1, 1939, whthe German invasion of Poland began, followed by the declaration of war by Britain and France against Germany on September 3, and in the Pacific, the beginning date of the war is the beginning of the Second Japanese-Chinese War on July 7, 1937, so that some consider the beginning date to be the Japanese invasion of Manchuria on September 19, 1931.

Public health services are universal and available to all citizens of the State free of charge. In any case, taxes finance the construction and maintenance of health centres and hospitals, with the State spending about 9% of its GDP on the health sector. Statistics for 2012 indicate that there are 1.85 doctors and 2.3 beds in Brazilian hospitals per 1,000 inhabitants. Public health problems persist in Brazil despite the progress made since the establishment of the comprehensive health-care system in 1988, with the main problems to be solved in 2006 being high infant mortality rates (2.51 per cent) and maternal mortality rates (73.1 per 1,000 births). The Brazilian health sector is affected by other figures, such as the number of deaths from non-communicable diseases, such as cardiovascular diseases (151.7 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants) and cancer (72.7 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants). Preventable external factors such as car accidents, violence and suicide caused 14.9% of the country ' s total deaths. The Brazilian health system was ranked 125th out of 191 countries valued by the World Health Organization (WHO) in 2000. The Federal Constitution and the National Education Controls Act and its foundations provide for the duty of the Federative Government of Brazil, its states, federal provinces and municipalities to administer and regulate their own education systems. These public education systems are responsible for supporting themselves, by managing their own funding and associated mechanisms and securing sources of funding. The Constitution allocates 25% of the State budget and 18% of federal and local taxes to the education sector. The literacy rate was 93.4% of Brazilians, according to figures from the Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics (IBGE) in 2019, meaning that 11.3% of the population (6.6%) are still illiterate, with the literacy rate reaching about 97% in some states such as Rio de Janeiro and Santa Catarina, with functional illiteracy equivalent to 21.6% of the population.

After the early 2003 election, in which the right-wing list of Pem Fortein lost most of its seats, a new tripartite government was formed with the participation of the Christian Democratic Appeal Party, the People ' s Party for Freedom and Democracy and the Democrats ' Party 66. The Government has introduced an ambitious programme aimed at reforming welfare State systems, public health care and migration policy. The Government did not last long as it soon fell in June 2006, whits smaller partner, the Democrats ' Party 66, put forward a motion to deny confidence to the Minister of Immigration and Community Integration Rita Verdonek, who belonged to the People ' s Party for Freedom and Liberal Democracy, the second partner of the coalition. Verdonek had instructed an inquiry into doubts about the validity of asylum procedures under which the Somali MP, Ian Harsi Ali, had acquired Dutch citizenship belonging to the People ' s Party for Freedom and Democracy (PPL), raising questions about the political integrity and credibility of Deputy Ian Harsi and about the extent and depth of the differences among liberals. The tripartite coalition collapsed and a business government was formed that included the People ' s Party for Freedom and Democracy and the Christian Democratic Appeal until the 22 November 2006 general elections. In those elections, the Christian Democratic Appeal Party maintained its status as the largest party in the country, while the Socialist Party made the greatest gains. The formation of the new Government took three months of negotiations and ended with a coalition from the middle left that included the Christian Democratic Appeal Party, the Christian Union and the Dutch Labour Party. But the government of the Central Left Coalition did not complete its mandate. The coalition was again over-contracted and the government collapsed on 20 February 2010, whthe Dutch Labour Party refused to renew the Dutch army's stay in Uruzkan State in Afghanistan. Early elections were held on 9 June 2010, with devastating results for the Christian Democratic Appeal Party, which lost nearly half of its seats in the House of Representatives to 21.

The wave (also called wave collection) in physics is a form of energy transmission, which moves in a physical medium (except for electromagnetic waves and some forms of quantum molecules with wave characteristics), where waves move and energy moves from one place to another without permanently dislodging the middle molecules, i.e. no mass is transported with the wave moving, but the middle molecules move in a deliberate way or parallel to the direction of the wave movement around a fixed position. The electromagnetic waves spread into the vacuum, i.e. without the need for a physical medium. Light, radio waves, X-rays and gamma rays are examples of electromagnetic waves. One characteristic of the electromagnetic wave is that it spreads into the vacuum at the speed of light, the speed of which is estimated at 299,792,458 metres per second. Waves are usually a frequency of some type of intensity in successive intervals at a intervals betwethem, and the number of waves passed in a segment divided by the unit of time is called frequency. The horizontal distance of one wave is called wavelength. The waves are spread in multiple types of physical media, which require some coherence to ensure transmission of wave signals, and the waves can be classified according to their physical properties: waves are characterized by a combination of physical behaviors: waves can be divided into length waves and accidental waves. Spinal waves (reviewed) in a flexible medium (e.g. solid body and free surface of liquid) whose molecules have sufficient coherency forces to enable the vibrating molecule to move its adjacent molecules vertically in the direction of wave proliferation. There are two types of wave: f=1-T{displaystyle f=1-T} where T is the time of each period (cycle). d is the frequency of the wave and its standard Hz unit, or 1/second. N is the time betwethe beginning and the end of one wave, or the time betwetwo successive peaks.

The Red Sea is higher than the Eastern Mediterranean Sea, and the Canal is therefore the tidal strait that pours the waters of the Red Sea into the Mediterranean Sea. For bitter lakes, which are highly salted natural lakes forming part of the Canal, the migration of red sea organisms to the Mediterranean has beprevented for decades, but after the gradual equivalence of lake salinity with the Red Sea, the barrier that prevented the migration of these organisms has beremoved, and plants and animals that migrate from the Red Sea have begun to colonize the Eastern Mediterranean. The Red Sea is generally considered to be more salty and less food resources than the Atlantic Ocean, and therefore the Eastern Mediterranean is considered to have less food resources for red sea organisms than Atlantic organisms. Accordingly, it is the Red Sea that invaded local Mediterranean organisms, not the other way around; this phenomenon is known as the migration of marine organisms. The construction of the high dam in Aswan, which cuts off the Nile River in the 1960s, has reduced the flow of fresh water and nutrients rich from the Nile to the Eastern Mediterranean, thus exacerbating the conditions for the impact of invasive organisms. Invasive organisms have become a major component of the Mediterranean ecosystem and have serious impacts on the sea environment, threatening many local and endemic species. In the first look at some groups of aliorganisms, it appears that over 70% of the native non-indigenous deciles of legs and about 63% of the Mediterranean exotic fish originating from the Indian Pacific Ocean are considered to be aliorganisms on the Mediterranean Sea via the Suez Canal. This makes the channel the first route to reach the Mediterranean invasive organisms. The impact of some migratory marine organisms has befound to be significant, particularly in the Mediterranean Shami basin, where local organisms have bereplaced and converted into familiar.

Earth Day, an annual event celebrated around the world on April 22 to show support for environmental protection. Earth Day was first celebrated in 1970, and now includes events organized worldwide by the Earth Day Network in more than 193 countries around the world. The historic Paris Convention was signed by the United States, China and some 120 other countries on Earth Day in 2016. The signing of the Convention included a key requirement for the entry into force of the historic draft of the Climate Protection Treaty, adopted unanimously by 195 States present at the 2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris. Peace activist John McConnell, at the 1969 UNESCO Conference in San Francisco, proposed a day to honour the Earth and the concept of peace, which was first celebrated on March 21, 1970, the first spring day in the northern hemisphere. The Nature Balance Day was later endorsed in a declaration writtby McConnell and signed by Secretary-General U Thant at the United Nations. A month later, American Senator Gaylord Nelson founded a separate Earth Day as the first environmental awareness day on April 22, 1970, and Nelson later received the Presidential Order of Freedom in recognition of his work. WhLand Day was set on April 22, in the United States, an organization launched by Dennis Hayes, the main national coordinator in 1970, made Earth Day a world day in 1990, and evorganized the event in 141 countries. Many societies are celebrating Earth Week, an entire week of activities focusing on the environmental issues facing the world. The Science March took place on Earth Day in 2017 (22 April 2017) and was followed by the People ' s Climate Alert (29 April 2017).

The mass of great black holes is betwemillions of solar blocks to billions of solar blocks, and in most cases appears to be found in galaxies' centers, and how those black holes and their relationship to the formation of a galaxy around them are still under the research of astronomers. A powerful radio source in the center of our galaxy is the Milky Way galaxy, which has a heavy radio radiator called A* (or a short Sgr A* or in Arabic: an arami a*) mass of about 4.3 million solar blocks, and its mass was estimated years ago on the basis of near-gas clouds (such as a so-called small spiral arm) which resulted in a mass of 2.7 million solar blocks, but the use of higher variation and more sensitive telescopes has enabled scientists to deduce its mass at the center of the galaxy by watching nearby star orbits and their proximity to orbits around it, such as S0-102 and S2 star, and recent observations have shown that its mass is much larger; it is 4.3 million solar blocks. The sightings indicate that black holes may have formed with galaxies at the same time and that they have helped to form a galaxy around them, and this is an important subject that scientists are interested in explaining. In the middle of the Milky Way galaxy, the target radio source A* (Sgr*A) is a massive black hole of 4.3 million solar blocks. A few years ago, mass estimation depends on gas withdrawal control (e.g., called mini-spiral), still at about 2.7 million solar blocks. Thanks to improved accuracy and sensitivity of telescopes, the mass of the black hole in the center of the galaxy can be more accurately determined by a path analysis, e.g. the stars S0-102 or S2 that orbit the black hole.

Thermocouple is an electrical component used to measure temperatures. This type of measurement is of great importance in measuring high-value temperatures. One of its advantages is low manufacturing cost, strong design and user-friendly especially whused in complex and variable standard systems. The double consists of two different metal that are connected to each other at the tip of the double. Whthere is a thermal variation at the tip of the double which in turn contains the sides of the different metals, there is an electrical tension proportional to the temperature passing through each of the metals. The more heat the metal, the more power it generates. So each side passes to a metal, different heat from the other metal corridor, and two different electric currents reach the other end. At this end, which binds the metal together, an electrical effort is generated because there is a variation in currents. An electronic component measures this generated effort, converts its value as needed to the thermal value shown on display, or passes the value to another component for use in another standard machine or the like. The scientific background of the modus operandi depends on the Sibek coefficient discovered by the German scientist Thomas Sebeck. Whthe heat of a metal changes, its electrons move faster. Whthe velocity of electrons in the two related metals varies in the thermocouple, the electrons overlap with each other where the metal meets. And that's where there's a surplus of electrons on one side, and a shortage of electrons on the other. This difference generates an electrical current that relates to the metal type on the one hand, and heat on the other. This current is called the electro-thermal current. These two currents are connected to an electronic board, where the current difference is measured by a microvolt based on a thermal difference of one calvin. The value of the electro-thermal current in microvolt per 1 Kelvin is a heat differential.

In the 13th century, the Sultanate of Egypt extended its control over the Levant until it was defeated by the Ottoman State in 1517. During the nineteenth century, the national awakening among Jews led to the establishment of the Zionist movement in the diaspora, followed by waves of migration to Ottoman Syria and later mandated Palestine. In 1947, the United Nations adopted a plan for the partition of Palestine recommending the establishment of independent Arab and Jewish States and international Jerusalem. The plan was accepted by the Jewish Agency, while rejected by Arab leaders. The following year, the Jewish Agency declared the independence of the State of Israel, and the subsequent Arab-Israeli war of 1948 saw Israel on most of the former lands of assignment, while the West Bank and Gaza Strip were under the control of neighbouring Arab States. Since then, Israel has fought several wars with Arab States. Since the Six Day War of 1967, Israel has occupied both the West Bank and the Golan Heights and the Gaza Strip (still considered occupied after the disengagement in 2005, although some legal experts oppose this claim). Its laws had beextended to include the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem, but not the West Bank. Israel ' s occupation of Palestinian territories is the longest military occupation in the world in modern times. Efforts to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict have not resulted in a final peace agreement. However, peace treaties have besigned betweIsrael, Egypt and Jordan. In its basic laws, Israel defines itself as a Jewish, democratic and nation State of the Jewish people. The country enjoys a liberal democracy (one of only two countries in the Middle East and North Africa region, and the other is Tunisia), with a parliamentary system, proportional representation and universal suffrage. The Prime Minister is the Head of Government and the Knesset is the Legislative Council. As of 2019, Israel is a developed country and a member of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), with 31 or 32 largest economies in the world by gross domestic product (GDP).

Abortion is a language of an abortion that stopped growing before completion, or an abortion is an incomplete organ; in the language of dropping the fetus; the mother's delivery to her child before completion; it is an abortion. It is also called ablution in the sense that it causes abortion. It is the termination of the pregnancy by leaving or removing the fetus from the womb before he becomes able to live. Abortion can occur automatically because of complications during pregnancy and is called spontaneous abortion. Abortion induced to maintain a pregnant woman ' s health status is known as therapeutic abortion, while induced abortion for any other reason is known as voluntary abortion. The term abortion oftrefers to induced abortion. Inducing abortion is one of the safest medical procedures in the developed countries where the law allows it to be performed. The Oxford Lexicon defines this operation as the deliberate termination of a human pregnancy, oftcarried out during the 28th week of pregnancy. Abortion has a long history and has beperformed, inter alia, through herbs, the use of sharp instruments, physical trauma and other traditional methods. Contemporary medicine uses drugs and surgical procedures to induce abortion. Sharia, custom and culture have different views on abortion from country to country. There is debate in many countries about the ethical and legal extent of abortion. Abortion and related issues play a prominent role in national political life in many States and oftinvolve opposition on the part of movements opposed to abortion, and support on the part of supporters of wom' s right to choose around the world. Abortions have declined worldwide, in conjunction with increased family planning, education and contraceptive services. The number of abortions in the United States of America decreased by 8% from 1996 to 2003. Automatic abortion is the release of the foetus from the womb due to accidental trauma or natural causes and usually occurs before the twenty-second week of pregnancy; the definition of the age of pregnancy varies from country to country.

Jerusalem is characterized by the Mediterranean climate (Csa Cobin classification), with a dry hot summer, and a mildly cold winter. Snow usually falls once or twice during winter, although the city experiences a high snowfall once every three to four years, on average, with a short-lived accumulation. January is the coldest month of the year, with an average temperature of 9.1°C (48.4°C); July and August are the hottest, with an average temperature of 24.2°C (75.6°C), and summer months are usually dry. The average annual rainfall is about 537 mm (21 inches) betweOctober and May, while the other months are mostly out of rainfall. Snowfall is not common, but heavy snowfall is rare. Jerusalem received more than 30 cm (12 inches) of snow on December 13, 2013, which almost crippled the city. With average summer temperatures similar to the coasts, the Mediterranean sea influence is strong, especially givthat Jerusalem is on a latitude similar to the warm deserts not far to the east. The highest temperature recorded in Jerusalem was 44.4 °C (111.9°C) on 28 and 30 August 1881, and the lowest temperature recorded on 25 January 1907 was -6.7 °C (19.9°C). Most air pollution in Jerusalem comes from car traffic. Many major streets in Jerusalem have not bebuilt to accommodate this large volume of traffic, resulting in traffic congestion and more carbon monoxide emissions in the air.

Before the arrival of the Inca, a variety of different families of indigenous Americans who settled in Ecuador emerged. Some sailed to Ecuador on a raft from Central America, others came to Ecuador via the Amazon rafts, others came from North South America, and others went up from the southern part of South America through the Andes or by sailing on boats. These groups eventually came with similar cultures, although their languages were irrelevant, and evthough they lived in the same environment. People from the coast have befishing, people from the high Andes have befarming, and people from the Amazon basin have befishing on the old nomadic roads. Whthe Inca arrived, they found that these continents were designed so that the Inca took two generations of rulers - Toba the Inca Yubanki and Huaina Kapak - to accommodate these continents in the Inca Empire. The inhabitants of the indigenous continents, which were the cause of most of the problems, were deported to remote areas of Peru, Bolivia and northern Argentina. Similarly, a number of sincere Inca subjects from Peru and Bolivia were brought to Ecuador to prevent the insurgency. Thus, the Ecuadorian Highlands became part of the Inca Empire in 1463, which shared the same language. In contrast, whInca continued to invade coastal and eastern Ecuador and the Amazon jungles in Ecuador, they found both the environment and the indigenous population more hostile. Moreover, whthe Incas tried to subdue them, the indigenous peoples withdrew into the interior and resorted to guerrilla tactics. As a result, inca expansion in the Amazon basin and the Pacific coast of Ecuador was hampered. Indigenous peoples in the Amazon forests and coastal areas of Ecuador remained relatively independent, evSpanish soldiers and missionaries who had difficult access to them.

Dr. Said Chepan (2 April 1925 - 4 December 2022) is an Algerian professor in Laayoune, former Minister of Religious Affairs and Waqfs of the First Government of Ould Hamroush (9 September 1989 to 25 July 1990), the Second Government of Hamroush (25 July 1990 to 4 June 1991) and former President of the Algerian Muslim Society of Scientists, and the brother of Sheikh Abdulrahman Cheban. The high school was transferred for a year to the teacher training school in Bouzaria. He dropped out of school from 1942 to 1943 because of the bombing of the Bejo High School (now Prince Abdul Qader) by German aircraft. After the English and American entered Algeria, he returned to his town to the Old Mosque to learn Arabic well and was studied by Sheikh Erzaki bin Shablah. In July 1946, he received a certificate of baccalaureate and joined the Algerian Islamic Scout and the secret activity of the Algerian People ' s Party. He thtravelled to Germany and joined the University of Strasbourg. In March 1956, he participated in the Congress of the Algerian Students ' Union in Paris and met Mohamed Sadiq BYahi and Radha Malik. He participated in the Strasbourg conference with Ahmed Taleb Brahimi, Belaid Abdussalam, Mohamed Sadiq BYahya and others. He participated in the student strike in May 1956. Thin July 1958, he presented his thesis, which was ready two years ago. In 1959, he passed the ophthalmology exam. In May 1962, he supervised the Tizi and Zou Hospital at the request of the National Liberation Front (NLF) and remained in it for six years.

The Catalan Club logo went through several stages of evolution and change. The first logo of the club was a crown, above and above a bat, with a number of yellow, red and white lines, used from 1899 to 1910, the bat symbolized freedom. The bat symbolized greatness and had no political connotations at the time. The bat was colored in Catalonia (yellow and red) as a symbol of the identity of the Catalan Club. In 1910, the theme of the club changed and became typical today: on the left side up there is a red cross (+) surrounded by white, the symbol of St. Jargus, and on the right side up there are yellow and red lines and they symbolize Catalonia, the territory of the club and Barcelona, and at the bottom of the logo are blue and red lines and those lines symbolize the club. The former club player Carlis Komamala is an innovator of the club's logo after the club organized a design competition in 1910 to be a logo for the club and the design of that player was selected. The club logo has undergone a number of minor changes during its history, either for political reasons or for reasons related to the introduction of certain aesthetics to the club logo. Del Parsa () was the official anthem of the club, which began in 1974 at Camp Nu on the occasion of the club's seventy-fiveth anniversary of the club, by Jamie Peckas and Joseph Maria Espinosa, and by Manuel Falls Gorina.

These stars are said to be in the main sequence and are called dwarf stars. Starting at 0 hrs in the main sequence, helium at the core of the star is increasing steadily, the rate of nuclear integration at the core of the star will slowly increase, as will the temperature and brightness of the star. The Sun, for example, is estimated to have increased its brightness by about 40% since it reached the main sequence stage 4.6 billion (4.6 x 109) years ago. Each star generates star winds from primary particles (mostly protons and neutrinos) that flow continuously into space, for most stars the amount of mass lost with those winds is modest. The Sun loses 14 - 10 percent of its solar mass each year because of the mass becoming energy during nuclear fusion and because of particles released from it into space, or about 0.01% of its total mass per year. Nevertheless, a number of very large stars may lose 10 - 7 to 10 - 4-5 from its solar mass each year, affecting its significant development. Stars starting with more than 50 solar blocks may lose more than half of their mass while remaining in their main sequence. The length of the star in the main sequence depends primarily on the amount of fuel that integrates and the rate of hydrogintegration, i.e., its primary mass and glow. For the sun, its life is estimated to be about 10 billion (1010) years. Large stars consume their fuel very quickly and short-term, with very high temperature, reaching billions of degrees. Low-mass stars consume their fuel very slowly and react at lower temperatures (about 12 million degrees Celsius). The stars of less than 0.25 solar mass are called: red dwarfs are able to integrate hydroginto nearly its mass as fuel, while stars with a mass of 1 solar mass can consume only about 10% of their mass as fuel.

The lost astronaut is an aluminum sculpture made to commemorate the memory of the astronauts who died for scientific research and exploration of the universe, about 8.5 cm long and embodying a space pilot in his suit, put by the crew of the Apollo 15 spacecraft on the foot of Mount Hadley Rella on the Moon on August 1, 1971. They agreed that Van Huydonck would carve a small statue to be placed on the moon by Scott, although they differed in detailing the meeting, according to Scott ' s novel, the purpose of which was to commemorate the astronauts who had lost their lives in space exploration, and Scott designed a painting separately containing the names of the dead astronauts. Van Huydonck, on the other hand, has giva series of design restrictions such as that the sculpture is light and strong, able to withstand maximum moon temperatures, and that the statue does not show signs of sex or race, in order to avoid commercial exploitation of space, and it has beagreed that Van Huydonck ' s name will not be declared public, but Huydonck denied this agreement. Van Hoydonk's novel carries a different set of events that led to the creation of work. He also stated that the name now called work was not his choice and he did not agree with it, and that he intended the statue to stand upright and not be on his back as it is now.

According to the Global Competitiveness Report of the World Economic Forum, the Dutch economy is the fifth most competitive economy in the world. Steel plants operate on the North Sea Canal near Amsterdam, relying on imported iron ore. Shipyards, submarines and yachts are located around Rotterdam. Endhovis one of the world's largest electronics companies, Philips, and its factories produce electronic machinery and tools, such as home appliances, radios, televisions and CDs, that are invented by the company, while other large Dutch industrial products include passenger cars, transport vehicles, small commercial aircraft and industrial machinery. A major industry is also processed food, including dairy products, especially butter, cheese, dried milk and eggs. The Netherlands is one of the largest cheese producers in the world. Food products also include sugar beet, chocolate and canned meat. Chemical industries include drugs, fertilizers, paints, plastics and industrial rubber. There are large oil refineries near Rotterdam. The textile industry produces cotton and wool textiles and industrial fibres. The Netherlands was also famous for the jewelry industry and the gem trade, where Amsterdam had long bea famous diamond cutting and polishing centre. The Netherlands is a first-class agricultural country. Some 70% of its land has beexploited in agriculture and grazing. However, the labour force in this sector is only 6% of the country ' s total labour force because of the extensive use of machinery and greenhouse-house farms at all stages of agriculture and harvesting. The Dutch cannot waste any land because of the country ' s limited size as a result of high population density, and farmers therefore permanently fertilize their land and use modern machinery. The average area of land used for agriculture is about 28% of the total area of the country. The most important branches of agriculture in the Netherlands are dairy farms, and the majority of the population cultivate crops that are mainly used to feed animals.

According to the 2011 German census, Christianity is the largest religion in Germany, with 66.8% of the total population. In relation to the total population, 31.7% declared themselves Protestant, including members of the Evangelical Church in Germany (30.8%) and the Free Churches (German: Evangelische Freikirch(0.9%), and 31.2% declared themselves Catholic. Orthodox Christians made up 1.3%, and other religions accounted for 2.7%. According to the latest data from 2016, the Catholic Church and the Evangelical Church respectively claimed ownership of 28.5% and 27.5% of the population. Both large churches have lost a large number of followers in recent years. In 2011, 33% of Germans did not belong to any of the officially recognized religious communities with special status. Latinism in Germany was stronger in the former East Germany, which used to be predominantly Protestant before the state was united, as well as in major urban areas. Islam is the second largest religion in the country. In the 2011 census, 1.9% of the population (1.52 million people) declared their religion Islam, but this figure is unreliable because a significant number of followers (and other religions, such as Judaism) used their right not to answer the question. Figures from Religionswissenschaftlicher Medi- und Informationsdienst indicate that there were 4.4 million Muslims (about 5.5 per cent of the population) in 2015. A study by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees found that betwe2011 and 2015 the number of Muslims increased by 1.2 million, mostly because of migration. Most Muslims are Sunnis and highs from Turkey, but there are few Shia, Ahmadiyah and other communities. According to the Pew Centre in 2016, there were about 5 million Muslims in Germany, representing about 6.1% of the total population.

The Litseng diamond mine is located in the Kingdom of Lesotho, a South African State that is closed and not at sea, owned by Jim Diamond and the Government of Lesotho. It is the largest diamond mine in the world, where it descends below ground to a depth of ~3,100 metres (10,000 feet). It has a very low ore (less than 2 carats/100 tons) but is well known for producing large pieces of diamonds, with the highest proportion of large diamonds (above 10 carats), giving it a dollar value per carat higher than any other diamond mine. The global average is about $81 per carat, while the average for the first six months of 2007 was over $1894 per carat. Because of the extreme depth of the mine, the mine ' s temperature drops to sub-20 degrees Celsius, and snow falls in winter routinely, but it is unusual for hot Africa. Lesotho Promise: Lesotho Promise announced its discovery on 4 October 2006 and weighs 603 carats (121 grams) of white diamonds, the largest diamond discovered in this century and ranked 15 in terms of the largest volume of discovered diamonds, the rarest stone color and class (D) of diamonds. Lesotho, Lesotho Brown, extracted from the land in 1967, was previously the largest discovered jewel in the Litsang mine and weighed 601 carats (120 grams). It was announced by Jim Diamond, a 493-carat-weight company, and ranked 18 as the largest diamond found. Graff-SAFDICO partnership was sold to Graff-Savedico and their partners for $10 million. It was extracted in 2004, and it weighs 123 carats. On 21 September 2008, Jim Diamond announced that it had found a 478 carat diamond of high quality, qualifying it to be 20 in terms of the size of the diamonds discovered.

The 1960 calendar began on January 1, 1960 and ended on December 31, 1969. The term refers to the cross-cutting cultural and political trends around the world in that era known as the 1960s. This definition of cultural contract is broader than actual contracts, as it began with Kennedy's assassination around 1963 and ended with Watergate's scandal around 1974. ∙ During the 1960s, Africa ' s transition from colonialism to independence accelerated considerably, as is known for the decision to decolonize Africa. Thirty-two States gained their independence from 1960 to 1968, representing the end of the European empires that dominated the African continent. However, the noble aspirations of these new nations quickly faded, and many nations descended into chaos, democracy, dictatorship and/or civil war, and the road to prosperity was difficult in most parts of the brown continent: by 2011, by many measures, Africa still had the largest poverty rate in the world and the lowest life expectancy. The United States-Soviet space race dominated the 1960s. The Soviets sent the first man, Yuri Gagarin, to outer space during the Vostok 1 mission on April 12, 1961 and recorded a series of other successes, but by mid-decade the United States was taking the lead. In May 1961, President Kennedy set the target of landing a man on the Moon by the end of the 1960s. In June 1963, Valentina Tereshkova became the first woman in space during the Vostok Mission 6. In 1965, the Soviet launched the first probe to hit another planet of the solar system (Venera 3), and the first probe to make the landing easy on the moon, Luna 9.

Although the Czech Republic had one of the most important pre-reform movements, there were few Protestant followers; this was mainly due to historical reasons such as the persecution of Protestants by the Habsburg Catholics, restrictions during communist rule, as well as persistent secularism. Over the past few decades, religious practice has declined with increasing secularism. According to a 2012 study on debt in the European Union conducted by Europarometer, Protestants made up about 12% of the European Union population. According to the Pew Research Centre, Protestants accounted for approximately five (or 18 per cent) of the continent ' s total Christian population in 2010. Clark and Pierre estimate that Protestants made up 15% of all Europeans in 2009, while Noel claims that less than 12% lived in Europe in 2010. Changes in Protestantism throughout the world during the last century have besignificant. Since 1900, Protestantism has spread rapidly in Africa, Asia, Oceania and Latin America. Philippines () is a constitutional republic in the western Pacific region of South-East Asia. It is an archipelago of 7,641 islands, bordered by Taiwan to the north by the Luzon Strait, and Vietnam to the west by the South China Sea. The Solo Sea in the south-west separates it from Borneo Island and Slips Sea to the south separates it from other islands in Indonesia. It is bounded from the east by the Philippine Sea. It is divided into three main geographical sections, namely, Luzon, Pisaia and Mindanao. Manila is the capital, while the most densely populated city is Quezon and both cities are part of what is called Metro Manila. The population of the Philippines is estimated to be 92 million, placing it in the 12th place globally according to the population census. It is estimated that there are 11 million Filipino expatriates worldwide. There are multiple races and cultures throughout the islands. Its tropical climate is one of the richest biodiversity regions in the world. The Nagreto ethnic of prehistoric times was one of the first inhabitants of the archipelago. They were followed by successive waves of Australian peoples with whom they brought influences from Malawian, Hindu and Islamic cultures. China ' s influence has also entered the country through trade. The arrival of Ferdinand Magellan in 1521 marked the beginning of an era of Spanish interests, which eventually led to the country ' s occupation. The Philippines became the Asian Centre for the Treasure Fleet of Acapulco, Manila. Christianity has spread widely in the country. As the twentieth century entered, events followed quickly and in a short period of time from the Philippine Revolution to the Spanish-American War, the Philippine-American War. Subsequently, the United States replaced Spain as a dominant force. Apart from the period of Japanese occupation, the United States retained sovereignty over the islands until the end of the Second World War whthe Philippines gained independence.

There are discussions about the criteria to be used to distinguish the "dual planet" system from the "tunnel" system. The considerations are as follows: the definition proposed by the International Astronomical Union calls for the two bodies individually to meet the clear orbital standard to be called a dual planet. One of the important considerations in determining "dual planet" is the ratio betwethe mass of the two bodies. The ratio of 1 betwethe two blocks indicates that the two planets are similar in mass, and objects with a close mass ratio tend to be considered as dual planets. Using this definition, Mars moons, buyers, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune can be easily excluded, because they all have less than 0.0025 mass of their planets orbiting around them. Some dwarf planets also have moons, but their mass is actually smaller than the mass of the dwarf planets themselves. The most noteworthy exception is the Pluto regime. The Sharon to Pluto bloc ratio is about 0.117 (approximately 2/17) and is close enough to one, so many scientists have consistently described Pluto and Sharon as "dwarf planets" (called double planets before the 2006 definition of the planet).

Coordinates: 48°50 ' 54 ' N 2°18 ' 15 ' E/ 48.8482 ' N 2.3042°E/ 48.8482; 2.342 ' ESA (European Space Agency) is an international organization dedicated to space exploration, with 22 member States, including Austria and Belgium (permanent member under a partnership agreement with the European Union in October 2008) Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. Canada and Finland are participating members. Founded on May 30, 1975 and based in Paris, France, the Agency has 2,000 employees from all over the world and its annual budget is Euro5.25 billion/$5.77 billion (2016). ESA and ISS jointly launch and operate several expeditions to the Moon and other planets, Earth observation from space, launch vehicle design and maintenance of a large space port. Apart from ESA headquarters, there are some sub-headquarters in Europe: many European scientists from Western Europe left, after the end of World War II, to work in the United States of America. Western European scientists realized that national projects alone would not be able to compete with the two main super-Powers at the time, despite the prosperity of the 1950s, which allowed Western countries to invest in scientific research, especially in space projects. In 1958, just two months after the Sputnik crisis, Eduardo Amaldi of Italy and Pierre Ujer of France - one of the most prominent members of the Western European scientific community - met to discuss the establishment of a joint Western European space agency. The meeting was attended by representatives of eight States, such as Harry Massey, the representative of the United Kingdom. The Western European States decided to establish two space agencies: one concerned with the development of launch systems, the European Launch Rules Development Foundation (ELDO), the other was previously the current ESA agency, and the European Space Research Organization (ESRO).

In 1860 Adolf Bastian (1826-1905) called for the idea of the psychological unity of mankind. It was suggested that a scientific comparison of all human societies would reveal that distinct global views are made up of the same essential elements. According to Bastian, all human societies share a set of basic ideas (Elementargedanken); different cultures, or Völkergedank' s different popular cultures), which are general amendments to basic ideas. That view paved the way for a more modern understanding of the concept of the word culture. France ' s Franz Boas (1858-1942) emerged not only from that view, but also brought it with him whhe left Germany for the United States. Although anthropologists around the world agree with Taylor Taylor's definition of culture, in the twentieth century the concept of culture emerged as central and unified in American anthropology, as it refers to human capacity symbolically and largely, which in turn reflects individual experiences symbolically, while linking these symbolic experiences in a social way. American anthropology can be divided into four fields, each of which plays an important role in the search for culture: biological anthropology, linguistics, cultural anthropology and archaeology.

Germany seeks to advance a more unified European policy, defence and security apparatus. The development policy of the Federal Republic of Germany is in itself a separate area from German foreign policy, with the Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development having the task of formulating and shaping this policy, which is being applied on the ground by the implementing organizations. The German Government sees development policy as a shared responsibility of the international community. Germany was the third largest global aid donor in 2009 after the United States and France. In 1999, Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder ' s Government developed a new-based definition of German foreign policy through participation in NATO ' s decision-making process with regard to the Kosovo war; Germany sent troops to the front of the fighting in a first step since the end of the Second World War in 1945. The Governments of Germany and the United States have a close political alliance. The 1948 Marshall Plan and strong cultural relations had established a strong bond betwethe two countries, although Schroeder was a opposition to the Iraq war, causing some relative coldness in German-American relations. The two countries were economically interdependent: 8.8% of German exports to the United States and 6.6% of German imports to the United States. Germany ' s population was approximately 80.2 million according to the 2011 census, and as of 31 December 2015 it was approximately 81.9 million, rising to 81.3 million in 2019. Germany ranked first in the European Union in terms of population and second in the entire European continent after Russia, and ranked 19 globally in terms of population. Its total fertility rate is one of the lowest in the world at 1.41 childrper woman (2011), and the German Federal Bureau of Statistics expects the population to decline to betwe65 and 70 million by 2060 (65 million if the annual number of immigrants is 100,000 and 70 million if the number of immigrants is 200,000 annually).

Brazilian law is based on the legal system of civil law, and the concepts of civil law prevail over the practice of common law. Most Brazilian law is codified, although non-compliant laws also represent a large part, and play a complementary role. Court decisions establish guidelines and interpretation; however, in other specific cases they are rarely binding. The work of jurists and academic jurists has a strong influence on the establishment of the law and the handling of legal issues. The legal system is based on the Federal Constitution of 5 October 1988 and the Organic Law of Brazil. All other legislation and court decisions must conform to its rules. As of April 2007, 53 amendments had bemade. The states follow their own constitutions, which must not conflict with the Federal Constitution, while the municipalities and the Federal District have basic laws (leis orgânicas), which are applied in a manner similar to the Constitutions. Legislative entities are the main source of laws, although in some cases judicial and executive bodies may enact legal controls.
